diagnoses.name: Von Hippel-Lindau disease
diagnoses.description: A rare, genetic multi-system disorder characterized by the growth of tumors in the kidneys, adrenal glands, the pancreas, and the nervous system, as well as capillary hemangioblastomas of the brain, spine, and eyes. It may present with hemangioblastomas, which can lead to symptoms including difficulty focusing vision due to retinal angiomas. Renal cysts and renal cell carcinoma can occur, contributing to chronic kidney disease. Pheochromocytomas may cause a variety of vascular anomalies.

diagnoses.name: Sturge-Weber syndrome
diagnoses.description: A neurological and skin disorder characterized by port-wine stain birthmarks in the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve area of the face, glaucoma, seizures, intellectual disability, and vascular anomalies of the brain. Angiomatous malformations can cause issues with vision focusing.

diagnoses.name: Neurofibromatosis type 1
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple noncancerous (benign) tumors of nerves and skin (neurofibromas) and areas of abnormal skin color (café-au-lait spots). Plexiform neurofibromas may compress organs leading to additional complications such as lymphadenopathy. Some patients may develop optic nerve gliomas, affecting vision.

diagnoses.name: Castleman disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that involves an overgrowth of cells in the body's lymph nodes and can lead to lymphadenopathy. Though not directly related to chronic kidney disease, vascular anomalies, or angiomata, its systemic impact and associated conditions may coincide with these symptoms in complex cases.

diagnoses.name: Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic condition characterized by skin lesions, lung cysts, spontaneous pneumothorax, and renal tumors. This syndrome is associated with an increased risk of kidney cancer, which can impact kidney function, potentially leading to chronic kidney disease.

diagnoses.name: Tuberous sclerosis complex
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder affecting cellular differentiation, proliferation, and migration early in development, leading to various symptoms including kidney disease (angiomyolipomas and cysts), retinal hamartomas which might affect vision, skin angiofibromas, and lymphangioleiomyomatosis which might lead to lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. The complexity of lupus makes it possible to suffer from lymphadenopathy, chronic kidney disease, and vascular anomalies.

diagnoses.name: Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome (Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia)
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation in the skin, mucous membranes, and often in organs such as the lungs, liver, and brain. These vascular malformations are called telangiectasias and arteriovenous malformations; they are a form of angiomata and can cause chronic bleeding and related complications.

diagnoses.name: POEMS syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare blood disorder that affects multiple systems, including the skin (with hemangiomata-like lesions), nerves, and organs. The acronym POEMS stands for polyneuropathy, organomegaly, endocrinopathy, monoclonal gammopathy, and skin changes. It may be associated with lymphadenopathy due to organomegaly.

diagnoses.name: Fabry disease
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder of lipid metabolism caused by the deficiency of an enzyme called alpha-galactosidase A. This leads to progressive lysosomal deposition of globotriaosylceramide in tissues, which can cause renal failure (chronic kidney disease), angiokeratomas (a type of angiomata), and might include vascular and ocular abnormalities affecting vision.

diagnoses: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS) - as a comorbid condition rather than a direct cause

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Osler-Weber-Rendu Syndrome (Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia)
diagnoses.reasoning: This rare genetic disorder can lead go epistaxis and gastroesophageal reflux. Obsessive-compulsive behaviors may be secondary to the stress of managing a chronic condition.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Affects various organs, causing symptoms like hearing loss, epistaxis, and could potentially lead to respiratory symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: An autoimmune disease that can cause dryness leading to hearing loss and gastrointestinal issues, though the connection to obsessive-compulsive behavior is less direct.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues, potentially impacting the gastrointestinal tract and nasal vessels. Hearing loss and dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests can also occur due to associated issues.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.reasoning: Directly causes gastroesophageal reflux; however, other symptoms like dyspnea could be related to complications or other coexisting conditions.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily affecting the body's connective tissue, it can lead to skeletal, eye, and heart problems, with potential links to the diverse symptom set through connective tissue disorder affecting various organs.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: This might lead to hypertension, thereby causing epistaxis. The link to other symptoms is less direct but could be related through associated conditions.

diagnoses.name: Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: This causes increased stomach acid production leading to gastroesophageal reflux. The connection to other symptoms such as epistaxis and dyspnea is less direct.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: An autoimmune disease affecting blood vessels could cause a range of symptoms including epistaxis and dyspnea, although hearing loss and GERD would be less commonly associated.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Obsessive-compulsive behavior is a hallmark. Dyspnea (not explained by pulmonary function tests), gastroesophageal reflux, and even epistaxis could be influenced by severe anxiety. Hearing loss is less directly connected but could be linked through associated stress or neglect of personal health.

diagnoses.description: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.details: A group of genetic connective tissue disorders characterized by unstable, hypermobile joints, stretchy skin, and tissue fragility. May explain hypermobility and could potentially link to systemic manifestations including fatigue.

diagnoses.description: Joint Hypermobility Syndrome
diagnoses.details: A condition that features joints that easily move beyond the normal range expected for a particular joint. Symptoms may include joint pain and fatigue. However, it doesn't directly explain blepharospasm, otitis externa, or dysosmia.

diagnoses.description: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.details: A complex disorder characterized by profound fatigue that is not improved by bed rest and may be worsened by physical or mental activity. While hypermobility is not a direct symptom, individuals with chronic fatigue syndrome may experience a wide array of symptoms including dysosmia.

diagnoses.description: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.details: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. Fibromyalgia could potentially link some symptoms like fatigue but not specifically blepharospasm or dysosmia.

diagnoses.description: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and central nervous system. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including muscle spasm (potentially relating to blepharospasm), fatigue, and sensory disturbances (potentially relating to dysosmia). However, it does not commonly direct towards hypermobility or otitis externa.

diagnoses.description: Parkinson's Disease
diagnoses.details: A progressive nervous system disorder that affects movement. Symptoms start gradually, sometimes starting with a barely noticeable tremor in just one hand. It can lead to stiffness and slowing of movement. Parkinson's may cause blepharospasm but is less likely to be associated with the other symptoms described.

diagnoses.description: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.details: Caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi transmitted to humans through the bite of infected black-legged ticks. Symptoms can include fatigue, facial palsy (can potentially resemble blepharospasm), and joint pain. However, hypermobility is not a symptom, and link to dysosmia is indirect.

diagnoses.description: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.details: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. It can also cause fatigue and joint pain and dysfunction, potentially linking to some of the symptoms. Direct links to hypermobility, blepharospasm, or dysosmia are, however, less evident.

diagnoses.description: Bechet's Disease
diagnoses.details: A rare disorder that causes blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. Symptoms can include mouth sores, eye inflammation, skin rashes, and lesions. Not directly related to the symptoms listed but can have a wide range of systemic manifestations.

diagnoses.description: Blepharospasm
diagnoses.details: A condition causing the eyelids to involuntarily blink or close. It is listed here as a diagnosis because it stands as a symptom on its own but can be considered a primary diagnosis in absence of identifiable systemic disorders. It doesn't explain the other symptoms but is directly related to one of the primary symptoms presented.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Hashimoto's Thyroiditis leading to transient hyperthyroidism

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV weakens your immune system, increasing your risk of various infections and certain types of cancer.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: Poorly controlled diabetes can lead to high blood sugar levels that may suppress the immune response and cause a predisposition to infections.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Can lead to xerosis (dry skin) and can affect the immune system, making the body more susceptible to infections.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: Can cause increased metabolic rate leading to symptoms such as hyperthermia and muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Compromised kidney function can lead to a decreased immune response.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can cause a wide range of symptoms, including increased susceptibility to infection, muscle pain, and dermatographic urticaria.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer of the lymphatic system can cause increased susceptibility to infections due to compromised immune system.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow with excessive production of ineffective white blood cells, leading to increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID)
diagnoses.description: A group of rare disorders caused by mutations in different genes involved in the development and function of immune cells. Patients with SCID are extremely vulnerable to infectious diseases.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: These disorders weaken the immune system, allowing repeated infections and other health problems.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Systemic lupus erythematosus (in rare cases presenting with urticaria)

diagnoses.name: Common Cold
diagnoses.description: A viral infectious disease of the upper respiratory system. Symptoms include nasal congestion and rhinorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction that causes sneezing, congestion, and rhinorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: A gastrointestinal disorder causing cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, diarrhea or constipation.

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infection
diagnoses.description: An infection in any part of the urinary system, could lead to incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Influenza
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that attacks your respiratory system. It's known to cause nasal congestion and rhinorrhea among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction that occurs soon after eating a certain food, could cause abdominal cramps and in severe cases, incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Eczema
diagnoses.description: A condition that makes your skin red and itchy. Pruritus is a common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the cavities around nasal passages (sinuses) become inflamed and swollen. This can result in nasal congestion and rhinorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An intestinal infection marked by diarrhea, cramps, nausea, vomiting, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Overactive Bladder
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a sudden, frequent urge to urinate that may result in incontinence.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Chronic kidney disease (related to systemic conditions)
Lupus with Central Nervous System Involvement
Drug Reactions (e.g., Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms [DRESS])
Viral Infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, Parvovirus, Dengue Fever)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Lupus erythematosus with associated lichen planus
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
